I.  PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
equity investment in Mekong Enterprise Fund II (the Fund) of up to $10 million or 25% of the 
Fund’s total share capital, whichever is less.  
 
II.  RATIONALE: BACKGROUND, CHALLENGES, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Background: Development of SMEs 
1.  Economic progress from a low base 
 
2.  Viet Nam has achieved substantial progress in moving forward from an extremely low 
level  of  development  in  the  early  1990s.  With  a  stable  political  regime  and  robust 
macroeconomic fundamentals, Viet Nam was among the world’s fastest-growing economies in 
2004 and is making good progress in further improving its policy environment.1 Industry and 
services, together accounting for nearly 80% of the gross domestic product (GDP), were the 
main  sources  of  growth,  recording  10.2%  and  7.4%  growth  respectively,  while  agriculture 
expanded the slowest at 2.8%. GDP growth is projected at around 7.6% for 2005, 7.6% in 2006, 
and 7.5% in 2007, supported by strong domestic demand and export growth. Since 2001 
Vietnamese authorities have accelerated the implementation of structural reforms needed to 
modernize the economy and to produce more competitive, export-driven industries. Viet Nam's 
membership in the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) and the establishment of the US-Viet Nam 
Bilateral Trade Agreement in December 2001 have led to even more rapid changes in Viet 
Nam's trade and economic regime. Viet Nam is working toward accession to the World Trade 
Organization, which is expected to foster its export sectors.  
 
2.  Emergence of SMEs 
 
3.  ADB’s Country Economic Review reckons that the development of the private sector is 
particularly important in Viet Nam, because it can have a significant impact on poverty reduction 
through its effect on growth and employment.2 Although the Government made only slow 
progress with its State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs) equitization (i.e. partial privatization) program, 
the private sector in Viet Nam has been growing rapidly since the mid-1990s, and particularly 
since the implementation of the Enterprise Law on 1 January 2000, when it became significantly 
easier to register new private companies. Since starting the equitization program in the early 
1990s, the government has partially privatized 2,450 SOEs. The SME sector, which is the main 
focus of this Fund, is still largely undeveloped. This is a reflection of the fact that the operation 
of large scale private sector enterprises was very difficult until the reforms of the 1990s and 
most private companies in Viet Nam were established as corporate entities only within the last 
10 years.  
 
4.  It is the growth of these private sector companies that is recognized by the Government 
to be the engine of growth. The development of SMEs can contribute to poverty reduction 
through contribution to economic growth, tax revenues, employment creation and individual 
income. Moreover, the diversification in the economy that will be brought about by SME growth 
in various industry sectors is a stabilizing factor.  
 
 
                                                 
1 ADB. 2005. Country Strategy and Program Update for the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 2006-2008. Manila. 
2 ADB. 2000. Country Economic Review. Socialist Republic of Viet Nam. Manila.

2         
3.   Cambodia and Laos  
 
5.  In Cambodia, private companies tend to be smaller than in Viet Nam, but nonetheless 
Cambodia has a reasonably thriving private sector. The absence of a state-owned sector in 
Cambodia has made it easier for private companies to establish themselves in all areas of the 
country’s economy. In addition to locally founded and managed companies, there are a number 
of private companies founded by overseas Cambodians who returned to Cambodia to establish 
businesses. There has also been foreign investment into garment manufacturing businesses in 
Cambodia, mainly by Taiwanese, Chinese and Korean companies. 
 
6.  Private companies in Laos are significantly smaller than in Viet Nam. It has been difficult 
for the Fund manager to identify private companies in Laos with annual revenues above $1 
million. Although market reforms instituted in 1986 with the New Economic Mechanism have 
had a positive effect on the Lao economy, there are only few registered private companies.  
 
7.  Although there have been no investments in Cambodia and Laos for Mekong Enterprise 
Fund  I,  the  Fund  manager  recognizes  strategic  value  in  keeping  its  investment  mandate 
regional to be able to take advantage of such opportunities if they arise in the future. As regional 
integration progresses, the Fund may also support Vietnamese companies in their expansion to 
Laos and Cambodia. 
 
B.  Challenges and Opportunities 
 
1.  Shortage of finance for private sector SMEs 
 
8.  Numerous market distortions still inhibit adequate supply of financing for private sector 
companies,  in  particular  SMEs,  including:  prioritized  lending  to  SOEs,  restrictions  on 
competition  from  foreign  banks,  high  collateral  requirements,  limited  project  appraisal  and 
business review capacity, and lack of transparent financial information. The supply of financial 
services  for  SMEs  comes  mainly  from  the  four  big  state-owned  commercial  banks,  which 
dominate the Vietnamese market with around 70% of all lending. The state-owned banks have 
high  levels  of  non-performing  loans  and  they  still  face  pressure  to  lend  to  state-owned 
enterprises even when commercial criteria might dictate otherwise. About 70 per cent of new 
bank credit is currently channeled to SOEs and, when agriculture is removed from the other 30 
per cent, only a very small amount of lending is actually to SMEs. The leasing industry is small 
with the main leasing companies being subsidiaries of the state-owned banks, and their main 
activities being lease finance for their parent companies.3 There is an even wider gap with 
respect to availability of equity finance. Due to legal and regulatory restrictions, foreign investors 
mainly invest through the foreign investment law and not directly into Vietnamese companies.   
 
9.  The existence of a private equity market is still negligible. The first private equity fund 
was introduced in Viet Nam in 1991. However, an extremely small private sector, slow economic 
and political reform, and weak domestic capital markets all contributed to a shortage of good 
investments at that time.4 The scarcity of attractive investment opportunities combined with the 
legal and regulatory limitations on foreign investment and the impact of the Asian financial crisis 
resulted in generally poor fund performance. Since 2000 the investment landscape has been 
improving steadily. As mentioned above, the acceleration of economic and political reform, 
                                                 
3  Department for International Development, 2003. SME Development and Pro-poor Economic Growth. Country 
Review. London. 
4  Sheela, W. Nguyen. V.D. 2004. Venture capital in a transition economy: the case of Viet Nam. Manila.

3
legislation stimulating the emergence of the private sector, the enactment of trade agreements 
and positive developments in the banking system, such as the opening of a stock exchange in 
July 2000, have created a more favorable operating environment for the private equity industry 
and the companies in which it invests. After a prolonged period of almost no activity from 1997 
to 2001, the private equity industry has restarted operations and new funds have been launched 
in recent years. However, underdevelopment of the stock market constrains the development of 
the private equity industry. Please refer to appendix 1 for a brief overview of the securities 
market in Viet Nam. These factors contribute to an extremely low private equity investment rate 
of  only  0.03%  of  GDP. 5  Equity  flows  are  further  constrained  by  numerous  investment 
restrictions, particularly on the use of foreign capital, and by the general opacity of the business 
environment, particularly for foreign and institutional investors.  
 
2.  Mekong Capital’s contribution to SME finance and development impact  
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELETED] 
 
10.  Mekong  Capital  (the  Fund  manager)  has  accumulated  unique  experience  in  SME 
finance in Viet Nam’s challenging operating and regulatory environment through its first fund, 
the Mekong Enterprise Fund I, which was launched with the support of ADB. This fund is now 
nearly fully invested. The Fund manager has gained a positive reputation with the companies in 
which it has invested, which will make it significantly easier to convince the owners of promising 
private companies that want the Fund as an investor to accept the Fund’s governance and 
transparency  requirements.  The  Fund  manager  has  dedicated  teams  to  add  value  to  the 
investee companies in accounting and finance, process improvements and human resource 
improvements. Since transparent  accounting   is  a   key  constraint  in Viet Nam,  the Fund  
manager  has  supported  the investee companies  to  improve accounting  and  financial  
reporting to provide a foundation for the shareholders and managers to make well-informed 
decisions.  The  Fund  manager  has  also  built  a  strong  core  competency  in  manufacturing 
process improvement, which is highly appreciated by portfolio companies and critical for future 
value creation. The Fund management team has demonstrated that it is able to introduce and 
promote  best  practices  in  Six  Sigma,6  lean  manufacturing;  activity  based  costing,  human 
resource systems and management reporting. This capacity building within portfolio companies 
contributes  to  sustainable  economic  growth  as  the  Fund  popularizes  best  practices  in 
manufacturing, finance and administration systems among Vietnamese companies.  
 
11.  In addition, the Fund plays a key role in improving the corporate governance of its 
portfolio companies thereby removing one of the main impediments to the development of Viet 
Nam’s capital markets. The Fund helps to solve this problem by working closely with private 
companies to implement high levels of transparency and internal controls, and encouraging and 
supporting them to be listed on Viet Nam’s stock exchange. In the context of a high aversion to 
transparency  in  Viet  Nam’s  private  sector,  the  Fund’s  portfolio  companies  set  a  positive 
example of the benefits of becoming more transparent. 
 
12.  The Fund manager has started to collect data on the predecessor fund’s development 
impact. In 2004, the predecessor fund’s portfolio companies have added 993 jobs, of which 143 
were technical jobs and 26 management jobs. While causality is difficult to establish, it is certain

that the fund’s equity investments made a key contribution to the SMEs’ expansion and future 
prospects.  
 
  3.  A catalyst for regulatory improvements 
 
13.  As the leading institutional investor in private companies in Viet Nam, the Fund manager 
has  been  among  the  first  investors  to  encounter  certain  regulatory  hurdles  and  takes  an 
organized approach to addressing and resolving them. For example, recently the Fund manager 
has  been  raising  issues  related  to  remittance  of  dividends  for  foreign  investors  in  private 
companies as well as the ownership restrictions on the industries in which foreign investors can 
invest in private Vietnamese companies. Mekong Capital maintains a Private Sector Obstacle 
Status  Report,  which  has  been  well  received  by  various  members  of  the  development 
assistance community. These reports have helped raise awareness of key problems facing 
private  sector  companies  in  Viet  Nam  and  investors  in  those  companies.  They  also  help 
interested parties, including ADB’s Mekong Regional Department and Government agencies, in 
their efforts to improve the regulatory environment for private sector development.   
 
III.  THE PROPOSED FUND 
A.  Objectives and Description 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELETED] 
 
14.  The Fund will focus its investment strategy on small and medium-sized enterprises 
(SMEs) with high growth potential in Viet Nam. The Fund may also consider investments in 
Cambodia or Laos, but this will be only on an exceptional basis, because physical proximity of 
the Fund manager to portfolio companies is a crucial factor for successfully investing and 
monitoring SME equity investments. The average investment size is expected to be $2.5 million.  
 
15.  The Fund aims to achieve an attractive net internal rate of return (IRR) by investing in 
equity and convertible securities of Vietnamese private and equitized (i.e. privatized) SMEs. The 
Fund may also invest in foreign companies or joint ventures with significant operations in Laos, 
Cambodia  or  Viet  Nam.  The  Fund’s  primary  focus  will  be  minority  investments,  usually 
representing 20% to 30% of the company’s total equity. The Fund may also engage in buy-outs, 
in which the Fund, either alone or in conjunction with third parties, takes a controlling stake. 
Buy-outs  will  only  be  considered  for  SMEs,  and  will  involve  upgrading  of  management 
processes that require the Fund manager to actively add value. The Fund will also have the 
ability to invest in companies domiciled in, or having significant operations in, Cambodia and 
Laos.  Fund  manager  closely  monitors  the  development  of  the  private  sector  in  Laos  and 
Cambodia, and the experience has been that on an exceptional basis there are companies that 
might be considered for an investment, in particular in Cambodia. However, it is important to 
note  that  the  Fund  manager’s  investment  strategy  requires  almost  daily  monitoring  of 
companies. Therefore, the Fund manager would have to be represented in Cambodia or Laos, 
which requires sufficient deal flow to justify the costs.  
 
16.  The typical target company for the Fund will most likely have the following characteristics:

B.  Fund Management  
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELETED] 
 
17.  The Fund will be managed by Mekong Capital (the Fund manager).  Mekong Capital is a 
well-established private equity fund management company with offices in Ho Chi Minh City. In 
order to make investments in the Hanoi area, and to provide post-investment assistance, the 
Fund manager intends  to  open  an  office  in  Hanoi  after  the  initial  closing  of  the Fund.  
The Fund manager has promoted and is managing the Mekong Enterprise Fund I (MEF I). This 
is an $18.5 million investment fund, which was launched in April 2002.  
 
18.  The Fund manager has a strong private equity team in Viet Nam with 12 Vietnamese 
investment professionals. The history of the private equity industry is short in Viet Nam, which 
translates into scarcity of private equity investment skills. In this context, the Fund manager has 
been able to develop systematic and well-documented processes relating to most areas of its 
operations, which has been essential for training investment professionals.  
 
19.  The Fund’s focus on improving transparency and adding value to its SME portfolio 
companies is reflected in its operational structure, which has a different emphasis compared to 
conventional private equity funds. The Fund manager has set up teams with an operational 
background who solely focus on recruiting for management positions, improving accounting 
systems,  enhancing  corporate  governance,  transferring  technology,  and  upgrading 
manufacturing processes by introducing Six Sigma and lean manufacturing. The resources of 
these teams, which consist of employees of the Fund manager, can be shared among all 
portfolio companies: 
 
(i)  Accounting  and  finance  team.  The  accounting  and  finance  team  consists 
mainly of former auditor seniors from “big-4” auditing firms, who are responsible 
for providing assistance to companies in areas relating to accounting systems, 
internal  controls  and  financial  management.  Improving  the  transparency  of 
portfolio companies is also a key requirement for achieving a listing on the stock 
market. 
 
(ii)  Process improvement team. The process improvement team consists mainly of 
Six Sigma black belts from multinational companies, who are responsible for 
providing  assistance  to  portfolio  companies  in  areas  relating  to  production 
management,  quality  management,  production  planning,  data  collection  and 
general process improvement.  
 
(iii)  Recruitment  coordinator.  The  recruitment  coordinator  is  responsible  for 
coordinating  the  process  of  finding  experienced  managers  for  portfolio 
companies.

6         
 
20.  The Fund manager has a strong reputation in the Vietnamese market, which is reflected 
in its ability to build a good investment pipeline for the Fund 
 
IV.  INVESTMENT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Justification of ADB Assistance 
 
1.  Development Impact 
 
21.  By providing financing to the Fund, ADB intends to achieve the following development 
objectives: 
 
(i)  Mobilization of long-term capital in the form of private equity for SMEs to 
finance expansion and productivity increases; 
 
(ii)  Diversification of sources of finance available for SMEs by inclusion of 
equity finance, which enables SMEs to buy fixed assets and to use them 
as  collateral  for  commercial  bank  loans  in  order  to  leverage  their 
expansion.  This  dynamic  process  helps  SMEs  to  become  larger 
enterprises and to eventually raise further capital by listing on a stock 
exchange;   
 
(iii)  Demonstrating to the private sector that investments in entrepreneurial 
SMEs in the Mekong region can be commercially attractive. The private 
equity industry in this region is still nascent, and ADB’s investment will 
support one of the few domestic private equity teams; 
 
(iv)  The Fund manager has developed unique capacity in value addition and 
established  dedicated  teams  in  accounting  and  finance,  process 
improvements and human resource improvements. In particular, the Fund 
will improve SMEs’ competitiveness by introducing best practices in Six 
Sigma,  lean  manufacturing,  activity  based  costing  and  management 
reporting;  
 
(v)  Improving  the  transparency  and  corporate  governance  of  SMEs,  and 
thereby addressing one of the key constraints of the Mekong region’s 
capital markets development. In addition, SMEs will increase their tax 
contributions  as  they  are  required  to  adopt  fully  transparent  financial 
reporting.  
 
(vi)  The creation of sustainable employment in the SME sector in Viet Nam, 
(and Laos and Cambodia if the fund invests in these countries); 
 
(vii)  Stimulation of private sector development that will serve as a vehicle for 
the country’s long-term economic progress and stability;

7
(viii)  Contribute to the development of a well functioning regulatory and legal 
environment through the reporting by the Fund Manager on regulatory 
issues that their SME portfolio companies encounter. This information will 
be reported on a regular basis to the Mekong Department to support the 
formulation of a conducive regulatory framework for expanding SMEs. 
 
  2.  Value added of ADB  
 
(i)  Demonstration Effect:  Given the significant risks and challenges facing 
potential investors as well as the nascent nature of Viet Nam’s private 
equity industry, ADB will serve a catalytic role in attracting additional 
private equity investors. ADB is playing an active role in structuring the 
Fund according to international standards of corporate governance, and 
has  been  a  strong  partner  of  the  Fund  Manager  since its  launch by 
advising on the strategy, management and fundraising for MEF I. ADB’s 
investment in the Fund will support one of the few domestic investment 
teams and help developing the nascent private equity industry.    
 
(ii)  Private Sector Development: The Fund, similar to others in which ADB 
invests, will make a direct contribution to private sector development.  
The Fund, with a portion of its funding coming from private investors, will 
employ market-based mechanisms to develop profitable and sustainable 
enterprises. The Fund will also contribute to the sustainability and growth 
of private enterprises by strengthening their financial structure, improving 
their transparency and introducing best practice manufacturing processes.  
 
B.  Measuring Development Effectiveness 
 
22.  PSOD will measure the expected development outcome of this Fund at the Fund and 
portfolio  company  levels  as  well  as  beyond  the  Fund  by  monitoring  certain  performance 
measures throughout the life of the Fund.  
 
(i)  Business performance (Fund) 
 
Overall profitability of the Fund: gross and net IRR. 
 
(ii)  Economic sustainability (portfolio companies) 
 
(a)  Efficient  allocation  of  finance  and  provision  of  financial  services  to 
economically viable enterprises. 
 
(i)  Sub-project  economic  performance:  annual  net  profits  and 
revenues of portfolio companies. 
(ii)  Stronger  local  entrepreneurship:  (a)  number  of  entrepreneurial 
projects  receiving  finance  from  the  Fund,  and  (b)  number  of 
returning  entrepreneurs  and  skilled  workers  from  industrialized 
countries receiving finance and transferring skills. 
(iii)  Contribution to widening the access to finance of SMEs: additional 
debt raised by subprojects as a result of the equity investments.

8         
(iv)  Provision of value-added services enhancing the viability of SMEs: 
(a) number of enterprises advised, and (b) quality of advice in 
financial  planning,  expansion  strategies,  human  resource 
development, accounting standards and corporate governance. 
 
(b)  Direct contribution of portfolio companies to the local economy and living 
standards. 
 
(i)  Contribution to government revenues: increased amount of taxes 
paid by portfolio companies. 
(ii)  Employment generated: (a) number of jobs created by portfolio 
companies, and (b) quality of jobs created by portfolio companies 
(e.g., technical jobs, middle management). 
(iii)  Adoption  of  new  or  improved  technologies  and  production 
processes:  (a) increased  investment  in  new  technologies  or 
improved production processes by portfolio companies, and (b) 
number  of  portfolio  companies  implementing  successful  new 
technologies. 
 
  (iii)  Private  sector  development  (impact  beyond  the  Fund  and  portfolio 
companies) 
 
(i)  New  technology,  development  of  management  skills,  and 
employee training in the domestic financial sector: (a) number of 
local investment professionals in SME private equity trained by the 
Fund,  and  (b)  number  of  the  Fund’s  investment  professionals 
raising a subsequent fund in a DMC. 
(ii)  Resource mobilization through private equity: (a) domestic finance 
for  investments  in  SMEs  mobilized  by  the  Fund,  and 
(b) international finance for investments in SMEs mobilized by the 
Fund.  
(iii)  Positive  effect  on  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  and  its 
administration: (a) quality and volume of the Fund’s feedback to 
ADB  on  improvements  in  the  regulatory  environment,  and 
(b) evidence  of  lobbying  of  the  Fund  for  improvements  in  the 
regulatory framework. 
(iv)  Growth  in  financial  services  in  the  domestic  financial  markets: 
(a) growth in the private equity market in the domestic financial 
sector, and (b) increased access to long-term finance.7 
   
V.  ASSURANCES 
23.  ADB will enter into suitable documentation that will indicate ADB’s commitment to invest 
an amount up to the lesser of $10,000,000 or 25% of the Fund’s total share capital following 
approval of the investment by ADB’s Board of Directors. ADB will not be largest investor in the 
Fund.  ADB  will  satisfy  itself  with  the  terms  and  conditions  of  the  all  principal  documents 
                                                 
7 Growth in financial services in the domestic financial markets will be measured at the level of the whole economy, 
not at the level of the Fund.

9
associated with its investment of the Fund, including the investment management agreement 
between the Fund and the Fund Manager.   
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
24.  I am satisfied that the proposed investment in Mekong Enterprise Fund II as described in 
this report complies with the Articles of Agreement of ADB and recommend that the Board 
approve the investment of up to the lesser of $10,000,000 or 25% of the Fund’s total share 
capital  in Mekong Enterprise Fund II from ADB’s ordinary capital resources. 
 
 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President
